awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will build on the widespread interest in the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) data principles for Open Science to synthesize and develop a consensus about next steps for the FAIR movement in the U.S. among representative organizations and thought leaders in the country.  The workshop will bring together a diverse group of experts and representative stakeholders from data and research communities, U.S. funders and mission agencies, and science societies, to seek input on the most promising concrete pathways for expanding uptake, integration, and implementation of the FAIR Principles in research practice and services.  

The primary aim of the workshop is to produce a scoping report that can serve as an agenda for the most promising strategies and approaches for FAIR capacity development incorporating the voices of academia, government, and industry.  This will be an invitational meeting which will seek diverse participants who are outside the well-known public voices on Research Data Management systems and services, while also including leaders who are working at the intersections of data infrastructure development, domain sciences, and open science.  International partners engaged in related initiatives will also be assembled for perspectives and experiences that will inform US efforts.  The goal for the workshop is to structure it as a series of highly interactive facilitated sessions with specific targeted outcomes that will contribute to the project report.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The pursuit of open science includes emerging practices around data, code, and related research materials that will improve access to information about research and its outcomes. The FAIR principles articulate basic aspects of Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reuse of research products, the metadata that describe them, and the identifiers that support linking them to each other, in and across the scholarly communication system. The promise of FAIR is that a broad increase in the application of the Principles will lead to efficiencies in scientific and scholarly production, and result in new discoveries and knowledge. The implementation of tools and technologies to make metadata, data, software and code, and other related products and processes FAIR will facilitate data integration, improve seamless service provision across resources and organizations; and, vastly improved (human and) machine readability of metadata and data that would increase reusability. 

Activities that lead to increased FAIR data capacity in the US will make for competitive advantage in our national research enterprise. Building networks of expertise among U.S. research communities working to develop and implement technologies for FAIR research products and services, and understanding current challenges to these efforts, contribute to the U.S. FAIR capacity. Toward these goals, a symposium was designed to gather the needs and concerns of the U.S. research community on approaches, implementations, and investments in FAIR data and code (and related products), introduce some European initiatives, and to further clarification of roles and responsibilities of the production and oversight of FAIR materials, tools, and services. Speakers and participants were drawn from academic, government, and private sectors; in addition to plenary talks and panels that covered a broad range of U.S. domain science efforts, leading experts in European FAIR organizations presented on successful initiatives underway there. Together, these virtual workshop events served to increase understanding and dissemination of leading FAIR developments and how they apply in the U.S., or cross-domain contexts. 

The "FAIR for US" virtual workshop and associated activities gathered input from across the U.S. research community on near-term achievable aims for the uptake of the FAIR principles in the production and dissemination of new knowledge. The symposium format served to strengthen and extend existing networks around FAIR data stewardship capacity in the US, and provided all participants with a better understanding of the landscape and replicable models for uptake and implementation. A scoping report that informs prospective, impactful community-led data initiatives is forthcoming.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Melissa Cragin
